As Denmark assumes the presidency of the Council of the European Union from July to December 2025, its foreign policy will play a significant role in shaping both the EU’s immediate agenda and its long-term geopolitical direction. Amid shifting global dynamics and rising tensions in the Arctic, the Danish government faces a complex leadership challenge. Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen and Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen have made climate resilience, migration reform and deeper European defence integration the central priorities of Denmark’s EU presidency. These priorities are designed to enhance the EU’s cohesion and global leadership.

Yet, Denmark’s evolving relationships with Greenland and the US will remain central to its diplomatic efforts in this period.Greenland, a self-governing territory within the kingdom of Denmark, is at the heart of Copenhagen’s Arctic strategy. Renewed US interest – reinvigorated by President Donald Trump’s administration, which has floated economic and military initiatives in the region – has unsettled European capitals and underscored Greenland’s strategic significance. We believe that Denmark may use its EU presidency to reinforce Greenland’s autonomy and promote stability across the Arctic. The Danish government is collaborating closely with Greenlandic authorities to strengthen infrastructure, coordinate defence and promote social inclusion - measures intended to bolster internal unity and deter external interference.Denmark has announced a significant increase in Arctic defence spending, amounting to approximately DKK14bn, with further investments anticipated throughout the year. The package encompasses the acquisition of three Arctic naval vessels, long-range drones, upgraded radar systems and broader satellite coverage across Greenland. Ongoing upgrades to military infrastructure are intended to reinforce Denmark’s presence and readiness in the region. These initiatives are part of a comprehensive Danish Defence Agreement, which enjoys broad bipartisan support and has been developed in consultation with both Greenlandic and Faroese governments.European counterparts - among them German Chancellor Friedrich Merz - have highlighted the increasing agreement within the EU that Arctic sovereignty should be addressed as a shared responsibility. Denmark is likely to leverage this solidarity to advance a more assertive EU Arctic policy, focusing on enhanced surveillance, environmental protection and indigenous engagement. The government has launched a USD2.0bn Arctic security plan, encompassing investments in naval assets, satellite surveillance and long-range drones. Prime Minister Frederiksen has also undertaken a diplomatic tour of Berlin, Paris and Brussels to rally support for a united European stance on Arctic governance and Greenland.This diplomatic outreach is already yielding tangible results. EU leaders have voiced strong support for Denmark’s position, increasingly framing Arctic sovereignty as a European issue. The EU is now actively considering several proposals, including:

Joint Arctic surveillance missions under the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy;

Expanded funding for Arctic climate resilience and support for indigenous communities;

A formal Arctic sovereignty declaration, reinforcing the territorial integrity of EU-associated Arctic regions. While a formal declaration is not yet finalised, there is growing momentum within EU institutions to adopt such a measure. This would serve as a diplomatic counterweight to external pressures - particularly from the US and Russia - and underscore the EU’s commitment to peaceful cooperation and rules-based governance in the Arctic.

Antananarivo - The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), in partnership with the Green Climate Fund (GCF) launched the Inclusive Agricultural Value Chains Programme (DEFIS+), that aims to boost resilience for smallholders, and both agricultural production systems and rural infrastructure. The programme will directly benefit almost half a million smallholder farmers and indirectly support over 3.5 million people in rural communities.



DEFIS+ is a six-year programme (2024-2030) that will promote sustainable agricultural practices and foster access to markets for smallholders across six regions in southern and central Madagascar. The total programme cost is US$ 150.8 million, with GCF financing US$ 53.9 million, and IFAD co-financing US$ 97 million through the ongoing DEFIS project (2018-2029). The strategic effort aims to bolster resilience and enhance food and nutrition security by building resilient agricultural value chains.

"DEFIS+ complements and pushes forward the achievements in our quest to strengthen climate resilience and bolster food security in Madagascar. This transformative additional financing will empower the programme to expand its interventions, address smallholders' challenges holistically and equip them with innovative solutions to support long-lasting resilience," said Sara Mbago-Bhunu, Regional Director for East and Southern Africa, IFAD.

Madagascar is the world's fifth largest island, and faces significant challenges in its agricultural sector, which is the backbone of its economy. With 59 per cent of its population living in rural areas and agriculture accounting for 23 per cent of GDP, the sector is crucial for the country's development. Recognised as one of the world's most vulnerable countries to the repercussions of climate shocks, Madagascar is engaged in various fronts to overcome the challenges caused by erratic weather patterns including prolonged drought. DEFIS+ will help to reduce the negative impacts of climate variability by applying adaptation measures.

"We are committed to working closely with IFAD, in alignment with the country's climate agenda, to deliver results that improve the lives and livelihoods of climate vulnerable communities." said Euan Low, GCF Sub-Regional Lead for East and Southern Africa Region.

June 4, 2025

Antananarivo - The International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), in partnership with the Green Climate Fund (GCF) launched the Inclusive Agricultural Value Chains Programme (DEFIS+), that aims to boost resilience for smallholders, and both agricultural production systems and rural infrastructure. The programme will directly benefit almost half a million smallholder farmers and indirectly support over 3.5 million people in rural communities.



DEFIS+ is a six-year programme (2024-2030) that will promote sustainable agricultural practices and foster access to markets for smallholders across six regions in southern and central Madagascar. The total programme cost is US$ 150.8 million, with GCF financing US$ 53.9 million, and IFAD co-financing US$ 97 million through the ongoing DEFIS project (2018-2029). The strategic effort aims to bolster resilience and enhance food and nutrition security by building resilient agricultural value chains.

"DEFIS+ complements and pushes forward the achievements in our quest to strengthen climate resilience and bolster food security in Madagascar. This transformative additional financing will empower the programme to expand its interventions, address smallholders' challenges holistically and equip them with innovative solutions to support long-lasting resilience," said Sara Mbago-Bhunu, Regional Director for East and Southern Africa, IFAD.

Madagascar is the world's fifth largest island, and faces significant challenges in its agricultural sector, which is the backbone of its economy. With 59 per cent of its population living in rural areas and agriculture accounting for 23 per cent of GDP, the sector is crucial for the country's development. Recognised as one of the world's most vulnerable countries to the repercussions of climate shocks, Madagascar is engaged in various fronts to overcome the challenges caused by erratic weather patterns including prolonged drought. DEFIS+ will help to reduce the negative impacts of climate variability by applying adaptation measures.

"We are committed to working closely with IFAD, in alignment with the country's climate agenda, to deliver results that improve the lives and livelihoods of climate vulnerable communities." said Euan Low, GCF Sub-Regional Lead for East and Southern Africa Region.
